abstract: In this work, a Scrum-Based New Product Development (SBNPD) approach is introduced. This new framework stems from the basis of Scrum and incorporates tools suitable for being applied to the design and development of physical products. The proposed approach implies that feedback from early adopters is to be gathered throughout the whole project, thereby driving to validated learning within a co-creation process.

abstract: Initial but limited evidence suggests yes: Larger IT firms have already integrated Agile and Stage-Gate and gained the benefits of both approaches; and most recently, a handful of manufacturing firms have employed this Agile–Stage-Gate hybrid model for physical new products. abstract: New product processes—formal “stage-gate” systems—have been widely adopted. While Second-Generation roadmaps represent a major improvement, they too have weaknesses. filename: XP-reprint.pdf
abstract: XP is a lightweight methodology for small-to-medium-sized teams developing software in the face of vague or rapidly changing requirements. It focuses on excellent application of programming techniques, clear communication, and teamwork. XP addresses both technique and good relationships to be successful.
harvard_citation: Beck, K. (n.d.). Extreme Programming Explained: Embrace Change.
keywords: software development; extreme programming; XP; methodology; agile; communication; teamwork; feedback; simplicity; courage; respect
original_filename: XP-reprint.pdf
title: Extreme Programming Explained: Embrace Change

filename: User_centered_design.pdf
abstract: User-centered design (UCD) is a broad term to describe design processes in which end-users influence how a design takes shape. It is both a broad philosophy and variety of methods.
authors: Chadia Abras; Diane Maloney-Krichmar; Jenny Preece
keywords: user-centered design; usability; human-computer interaction; design principles
original_filename: User_centered_design.pdf
source_url: In Bainbridge, W. Encyclopedia of Human-Computer Interaction. Thousand Oaks:
title: User-Centered Design

filename: Agile-Processes-for-Hardware-Development-cPrime.pdf
abstract: Hardware and software development are quite different, in terms of the concrete developmental activities. Thus it might seem that Scrum, the Agile process often used for software development, would not be appropriate for hardware development. However, most of the obvious differences between hardware and software development have to do with the nature and sequencing of deliverables, rather than unique attributes of the work that constrain the process. The research conducted for this paper indicates that a Scrum process is quite appropriate for hardware development. Thus this paper describes a practical Agile process for Agile hardware development, which is almost identical to the Scrum process as it is commonly used for developing software.
keywords: Agile; Scrum; Hardware Development; Software Development; Process
original_filename: Agile-Processes-for-Hardware-Development-cPrime.pdf
title: Agile Processes for Hardware Development

abstract: This e-book introduces the Modified Agile for Hardware Development (MAHD) Framework, explaining the differences between hardware and software Agile methods and highlighting the framework's unique elements. It provides tips on getting started with MAHD and addresses whether Agile is suitable for hardware development.
harvard_citation: Simpson, D. and Hinkle, G. (YYYY). *An Introduction to MAHD TM Modified Agile for Hardware Development Framework The Benefits of Agile, the Needs of Physical Product Development*. MAHD Framework LLC.

filename: AgileNPD_01_21.pdf
abstract: This research aims to bridge the gap between academic literature and industry practice regarding cross-industry implementations of Agile practices in new product development. The study expands the body of knowledge on the current state of Agile in new product development for not-purely-software projects and conceptualizes the differences in interpretation.
authors: Linus Gerdes; Dr. Rob Phaal; Dr. Valerie Lynch
harvard_citation: Gerdes, L., Phaal, R. & Lynch, V. (2021) ‘Agile New Product Development in Not-PurelySoftware Projects’, Centre for Technology Management working paper series, No. 1.
keywords: Agile; New Product Development; Manufacturing; Software; Cross-industry; Project Governance; Prototyping
original_filename: AgileNPD_01_21.pdf
title: Agile New Product Development in Not-PurelySoftware Projects
